defs.docs: A safe wrapper around the kernel's KVM interface.

attributes.value: ! A safe wrapper around the kernel's KVM interface.
! This crate offers safe wrappers for:
! **NOTE:** The list of available ioctls is not extensive.
! # Example - Running a VM on x86_64
! In this example we are creating a Virtual Machine (VM) with one vCPU.
! On the vCPU we are running machine specific code. This example is based on
! the [LWN article](https://lwn.net/Articles/658511/) on using the KVM API.
! The aarch64 example was modfied accordingly.
! To get code running on the vCPU we are going through the following steps:
! 1. Instantiate KVM. This is used for running
! 2. Use the KVM object to create a VM. The VM is used for running
! 3. Initialize the guest memory for the created VM. In this dummy example we
!    are adding only one memory region and write the code in one memory page.
! 4. Create a vCPU using the VM object. The vCPU is used for running
! 5. Setup architectural specific general purpose registers and special registers. For
!    details about how and why these registers are set, please check the
! 6. Run the vCPU code in a loop and check the
!         0xc6, 0x06, 0x00, 0x80, 0x00, /* movl $0, (0x8000); This generates a MMIO Write.*/
!         0x8a, 0x16, 0x00, 0x80, /* movl (0x8000), %dl; This generates a MMIO Read.*/
!             0x22, 0x10, 0x00, 0xb9, /* str w2, [x1, #16]; write to this page */
!             0x02, 0x00, 0x00, 0xb9, /* str w2, [x0]; This generates a MMIO Write.*/
!             0x00, 0x00, 0x00, 0x14, /* b <this address>; shouldn't get here, but if so loop forever */
!     // When initializing the guest memory slot specify the
!     // Write the code in the guest memory. This will generate a dirty page.
!     // 5. Initialize general purpose and special registers.
!         let mmio_addr: u64 = guest_addr + mem_size as u64;
!                     "Received an I/O in exit. Address: {:#x}. Data: {:#x}",
!                     "Received an I/O out exit. Address: {:#x}. Data: {:#x}",
!                     "Received an MMIO Read Request for the address {:#x}.",
!                     "Received an MMIO Write Request to the address {:#x}.",
!                 // The code snippet dirties 1 page when it is loaded in memory
!                 // Since on aarch64 there is not halt instruction,
!                 // we break immediately after the last known instruction
!                 // of the asm code example so that we avoid an infinite loop.

defs.name: Cap
defs.value: Cap::{Irqchip, Hlt, MmuShadowCacheControl, UserMemory, SetTssAddr, Vapic, ExtCpuid, Clocksource, NrVcpus, NrMemslots, Pit, NopIoDelay, PvMmu, MpState, CoalescedMmio, SyncMmu, Iommu, DestroyMemoryRegionWorks, UserNmi, SetGuestDebug, ReinjectControl, IrqRouting, IrqInjectStatus, AssignDevIrq, JoinMemoryRegionsWorks, Mce, Irqfd, Pit2, SetBootCpuId, PitState2, Ioeventfd, SetIdentityMapAddr, XenHvm, AdjustClock, InternalErrorData, VcpuEvents, S390Psw, PpcSegstate, Hyperv, HypervVapic, HypervSpin, PciSegment, PpcPairedSingles, IntrShadow, Debugregs, X86RobustSinglestep, PpcOsi, PpcUnsetIrq, EnableCap, Xsave, Xcrs, PpcGetPvinfo, PpcIrqLevel, AsyncPf, TscControl, GetTscKhz, PpcBookeSregs, SpaprTce, PpcSmt, PpcRma, MaxVcpus, PpcHior, PpcPapr, SwTlb, OneReg, S390Gmap, TscDeadlineTimer, S390Ucontrol, SyncRegs, Pci23, KvmclockCtrl, SignalMsi, PpcGetSmmuInfo, S390Cow, PpcAllocHtab, ReadonlyMem, IrqfdResample, PpcBookeWatchdog, PpcHtabFd, S390CssSupport, PpcEpr, ArmPsci, ArmSetDeviceAddr, DeviceCtrl, IrqMpic, PpcRtas, IrqXics, ArmEl132bit, SpaprMultitce, ExtEmulCpuid, HypervTime, IoapicPolarityIgnored, EnableCapVm, S390Irqchip, IoeventfdNoLength, VmAttributes, ArmPsci02, PpcFixupHcall, PpcEnableHcall, CheckExtensionVm, S390UserSigp, SplitIrqchip, ImmediateExit}

defs.name: open_with_cloexec
defs.docs: Opens `/dev/kvm` and returns the fd number on success.

attributes.value: / Opens `/dev/kvm` and returns the fd number on success.
/ One usecase for this method is opening `/dev/kvm` before exec-ing into a
/ process with seccomp filters enabled that blacklist the `sys_open` syscall.
/ For this usecase `open_with_cloexec` must be called with the `close_on_exec`
/ * `close_on_exec`: If true opens `/dev/kvm` using the `O_CLOEXEC` flag.
/ // The `kvm_fd` can now be passed to another process where we can use

defs.docs: Gets the recommended number of VCPUs per VM.

attributes.value: / Gets the recommended number of VCPUs per VM.
/ Default to 4 when `KVM_CAP_NR_VCPUS` is not implemented.

defs.name: get_nr_memslots
defs.docs: Returns the maximum allowed memory slots per VM.

attributes.value: / Returns the maximum allowed memory slots per VM.
/ KVM reports the number of available memory slots (`KVM_CAP_NR_MEMSLOTS`)
/ using the extension interface.  Both x86 and s390 implement this, ARM
/ and powerpc do not yet enable it.
/ Default to 32 when `KVM_CAP_NR_MEMSLOTS` is not implemented.

defs.name: create_vmfd_from_rawfd
defs.docs: Creates a VmFd object from a VM RawFd.

attributes.value: / Creates a VmFd object from a VM RawFd.
/ This function is unsafe as the primitives currently returned have the contract that
/ they are the sole owner of the file descriptor they are wrapping. Usage of this function
/ could accidentally allow violating this contract which can cause memory unsafety in code
/ that relies on it being true.

/ // Configure the struct to say which entries we want to get.

defs.name: set_user_memory_region
defs.docs: Creates/modifies a guest physical memory slot.

attributes.value: / Creates/modifies a guest physical memory slot.
/ * `user_memory_region` - Guest physical memory slot. For details check the
/ This function is unsafe because there is no guarantee `userspace_addr` points to a valid
/ memory region, nor the memory region lives as long as the kernel needs it to.
/ The caller of this method must make sure that:
/ - the raw pointer (`userspace_addr`) points to valid memory
/ - the regions provided to KVM are not overlapping other memory regions.

defs.name: signal_msi
defs.docs: Directly injects a MSI message as per the `KVM_SIGNAL_MSI` ioctl.

attributes.value: / Directly injects a MSI message as per the `KVM_SIGNAL_MSI` ioctl.
/ This ioctl returns > 0 when the MSI is successfully delivered and 0
/ when the guest blocked the MSI.
/ * kvm_msi - MSI message configuration. For details check the `kvm_msi` structure in the
/ In this example, the important function signal_msi() calling into
/ the actual ioctl is commented out. The reason is that MSI vectors are
/ not chosen from the HW side (VMM). The guest OS (or anything that runs
/ inside the VM) is supposed to allocate the MSI vectors, and usually
/ communicate back through PCI configuration space. Sending a random MSI
/ vector through this signal_msi() function will always result in a
/ failure, which is why it needs to be commented out.

Sets the GSI routing table entries, overwriting any previously set
 entries, as per the `KVM_SET_GSI_ROUTING` ioctl.

attributes.value: / Sets the GSI routing table entries, overwriting any previously set
/ Returns an io::Error when the table could not be updated.
/ * kvm_irq_routing - IRQ routing configuration. Describe all routes
/                     associated with GSI entries. For details check

defs.name: register_ioevent
defs.value: fn <T> (&self, fd: &EventFd, addr: &IoEventAddress, datamatch: T) -> Result<()>
defs.docs: Registers an event to be signaled whenever a certain address is written to.

attributes.value: / Registers an event to be signaled whenever a certain address is written to.
/ * `fd` - `EventFd` which will be signaled. When signaling, the usual `vmexit` to userspace
/ * `datamatch` - Limits signaling `fd` to only the cases where the value being written is
/                 equal to this parameter. The size of `datamatch` is important and it must
/                 match the expected size of the guest's write.

defs.name: unregister_ioevent
defs.docs: Unregisters an event from a certain address it has been previously registered to.

attributes.value: / Unregisters an event from a certain address it has been previously registered to.
/ This function is unsafe because it relies on RawFd.

defs.name: get_dirty_log
defs.value: fn (&self, slot: u32, memory_size: usize) -> Result<Vec<u64>>
defs.docs: Gets the bitmap of pages dirtied since the last call of this function.

attributes.value: / Gets the bitmap of pages dirtied since the last call of this function.
/ Leverages the dirty page logging feature in KVM. As a side-effect, this also resets the
/ bitmap inside the kernel. For the dirty log to be available, you have to set the flag
/ // This example is based on https://lwn.net/Articles/658511/.
/ // Initialize a guest memory region using the flag `KVM_MEM_LOG_DIRTY_PAGES`.
/ // ASM code that just forces a MMIO Write.
/     0x22, 0x10, 0x00, 0xb9, /* str w2, [x1, #16]; write to this page */
/     0x00, 0x00, 0x00, 0x14, /* b <this address>; shouldn't get here, but if so loop forever */
/ // Write the code in the guest memory. This will generate a dirty page.
/     // Set the Instruction Pointer to the guest address where we loaded the code.
/     let mmio_addr: u64 = guest_addr + mem_size as u64;
/             // On x86_64, the code snippet dirties 1 page when loading the code in memory
/             // while on aarch64 the dirty bit comes from writing to guest_addr (current PC).

defs.name: register_irqfd
